Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Section Header: Suicide Risk Management Protocol: Part D
Field Label: PART D: Characteristics of Suicide Ideation/Wish
1. How often do you have thoughts of suicide?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0, 0: Do they occur rarely, occasionally (zero, occasional)?|1, 1: Do they occur more frequently (intermittent)?|2, 2: Do you have thoughts most of the time, or all of the time (persistent, continuous)?

Field Label: 2. When you have thoughts of suicide, are they brief or last a long time?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0, 0: Fleeting|1, 1: Lasting a long time|2, 2: Persistent or almost continuous

Field Label: 3. Do you believe that you would be able to complete suicide, that is you know how to do it, you have the means and the motivation? Do you know exactly what you'd have to do to cause your own death, and do you feel that you would not hesitate to do it?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0, 0: No determination, does not believe he or she would be able to do it|1, 1: Unsure of ability, determination|2, 2: Sure of ability and determination

Field Label: 4. Does thinking about anyone or anything prevent you from trying to kill yourself?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0, 0: Would not attempt suicide because of deterrent|1, 1: Some concern about deterrent|2, 2: Minimal or no concern about deterrents

Field Label: 5. When you think about killing yourself, what are the main reasons?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0, 0: To manipulate the environment, get attention, revenge|1, 1: Combination of 0 and 2|2, 2: To escape, solve problems

Field Label: 6. Have you tied up loose ends because you anticipate killing yourself? For example, have you taken out an insurance policy or prepared a will? Have you started or finished writing a suicide note?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0, 0: None|1, 1: Started but not completed; only thought about it|2, 2: Complete

Field Label: 7. Sometimes people hesitate to talk about their suicidal thoughts because they fear others will think they're crazy or will make them go to the hospital. Could this be going on with you? If you had thoughts about suicide, would you tell someone close to you? Or would you hesitate?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0, 0: Revealed or would reveal ideas openly|1, 1: Held or would hold back on revealing|2, 2: Attempted or would attempt to deceive, conceal

Section Header: Suicide Risk Management Protocol: Part E

    A mild side effect is one that doesn't disrupt or interfere with your life and activities. A moderate side effect causes some disruption or interference. A severe side effect is so disruptive that you cannot function normally.)

Field Label:
See OPTIMUM Study Protocol for Adverse Event definitions and reporting procedures. The Redcap database will be the primary method for documenting Adverse Events. The presence of Adverse Events will be assessed at each timepoint by asking whether the patient has had any new problems with their health, but new AE's should be documented promptly if they occur between timepoints.

If clarification is needed:

  • Mild: Discomfort noticed, but no disruption of normal daily activity
  • Moderate: Discomfort sufficient to reduce or affect normal daily activity
  • Severe: Incapacitating, with inability to work or to perform normal daily activity

Note that determining expectedness should take into account the product information AND the population under study (depressed older adults).

Field Label: <font size=2, color="red">PLEASE RECORD THIS AS AN SAE.</font>
Difficulties in ability to concentrate, to collect one's thoughts, or sustain one's attention.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: The patient must try harder than usual to collect his/her thoughts, but not to the degree that it hampers the patient in his everyday life.|2, 2: The difficulties in concentrating are pronounced enough to hamper the patient in his everyday life.|3, 3: The patient's difficulties in concentrating are obvious to the interviewer during the interview.

Field Label: The patient's experience of lassitude and lack of endurance. <u>The assessment is based upon the patient's reported statements.</u>
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: The patient tires more easily than usual; however, this does not mean that the patient needs to rest more than usual during the day.|2, 2: Must rest now and then during the day because of lassitude.|3, 3: Must rest most of the day because of lassitude.

Field Label: Diminished ability to stay awake during the day.  <u>When possible, the assessment is based on clinical signs during the interview.</u>
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slightly sleep/drowsy as regards facial expression and speech.|2, 2: More markedly sleepy/drowsy.  The patient yawns and tends to fall asleep when there is a pause in the conversation.|3, 3: Difficult to keep the patient awake and to wake the patient, respectively.

Field Label: Impaired memory. <u>Assessment should be independent of any concentration difficulties.</u>
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slight, subjective feeling of reduced memory compared with the patient's usual condition; however, not interfering with functioning.|2, 2: The failing memory hampers the patient and or slight signs of this are observed during the interview.|3, 3: The patient shows clear signs of failing memory during the interview.

Field Label: Inability to relax, nervous restlessness.  This item is to be assed on the basis of the patient's experience and must be distinguished from motor akathesia.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: The patient states that he is slightly tense and restless; however, this does not interfere with his functioning.|2, 2: Considerable tension and inner unrest; however, without this being so intense or constant that the patient's daily life is influenced to any marked degree.|3, 3: The patient feels tension or restlessness that is so marked that his daily life is clearly affected.

Field Label: This should be assessed on the basis of the average of sleep over three preceding nights. The assessment is to be made in relation the patient's usual pre-illness state.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Sleep up to 2 hours longer than usual.|2, 2: Sleeps 2 or 3 hours longer than usual.|3, 3: Sleeps more than 3 hours longer than usual.

Field Label: Should be assessed on the basis of the average of sleep over the preceding nights.  The assessment is to be made in relation to the patient's usual pre-illness state.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Sleep up to 2 hours shorter than usual.|2, 2: Sleeps 2 or 3 hours shorter than usual.|3, 3: Sleeps more than 3 hours shorter than usual.

Field Label: Should be assessed independently of dream content and based on the average of sleep over the preceding nights in relation to the usual pre-illness dream activity.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slightly increase dream activity, which does not disturb the nights sleep, however.|2, 2: More pronounced increase of dream activity.|3, 3: Very pronounced increase of dream activity.

Field Label: A diminution of the patient's empathy, leading to apathy.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slight subduing of the patient's empathy.|2, 2: Obvious emotional indifference.|3, 3: Pronounced indifference so that the patient behaves apathetically in relation to his surroundings.

Field Label: Acute forms of dystonia in the forms of tonic muscular contractions localized to one or several muscle groups, particularly in the mouth, tongue, and/or neck.  The assessment is to be made on the basis of the last seven days preceding the examination.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Very slight or short spasms, for instance in the musculature of the jaws or neck.|2, 2: More pronounced contractions of a longer duration and/or a wider localization.|3, 3: Marked forms of, for instance, oculogyric crisis or opisthotonos.

Field Label: Increased muscle tone of a uniform and general nature, observed on the basis of a uniform, steady resistance to passive movements of the limbs.  Special importance is attached to the muscles around the elbow joints and shoulders.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slight rigidity in neck, shoulder, and extremities.  It must be possible to observe the rigidity on the basis or resistance to passive movements of the elbow joints.|2, 2: Medium rigidity assessed on the basis of resistance to passive movements of for instance the elbow joints.|3, 3: Very marked rigidity.

Field Label: Slow movements (bradykinesia), reduced facial expression, reduced arm swinging, reduced length of stride, perhaps leading to cessation of movement (Akinesia).
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slights reduced movement, for instance slightly reduced swinging of an arm when walking or slightly reduced facial expression.|2, 2: More clear reduction of mobility, for instance slow walking.|3, 3: Very marked reduction of mobility, bordering on and including akinesia, e.g. Parkinsonian mask and/or very short length of stride.

Field Label: Involuntary movements, most frequently affecting the oro-facial region in the form of the so-called bucco-lingual-masticatory syndrome. However, it is often also seen in the extremities, especially the finger, more rarely in the musculature of the body and respiratory system.  Both initial and tardive hyperkinesias are included.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slight hyperkinesias.  Only present intermittently.|2, 2: Moderate hyperkinesias present most of the time.|3, 3: Severe hyperkinesias, present most of the time with marked tongue protrusion, opening of the mouth, facial hyperkinesia, with or without involvement of the extremities.

Field Label: This item comprises all forms of tremor.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Very slight tremor that does not hamper the patient.|2, 2: Clear tremor hampering the patient.  The amplitude of finger tremor being less than 3 cm.|3, 3: Clear tremor with an amplitude of more than 3 cm and which cannot be controlled by the patient.

Field Label: A subjective felling and objective signs of muscle unrest, particularly in the lower extremities, so that it may be difficult for the patient to remain seated.  Assessment of this item is based on clinical signs observed during the interview, as well as on the patient's report.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slight akathesia; however, the patient can keep still without effort.|2, 2: Moderate akathesia; however, the patient can, with an effort, remain sitting during the interview.|3, 3: When the patient has to rise to his feet several times during the interview because of akathesia.

Field Label: Only generalized tonic-clonic seizures are to be recorded here.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: One seizure within the last six months.|2, 2: 2 or 3 seizures within the last six months.|3, 3: More than 3 seizures within the last six months.

Field Label: Pricking, creeping, or burning sensations in the skin.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Mild paraethesias, scrarely bothering the patient.|2, 2: Moderate paraesthesias, clearly bothering the patient.|3, 3: Sever paraesthesia, markedly bothering the patient.
1, 1: Slight headache.|2, 2: Moderate hampering headache which does not interfere with the patient's daily life.|3, 3: Pronounced headache interfering with the patient's daily life.

Field Label: Difficulty in seeing clearly or distinctly at close quarters (with or without glasses), whereas the patient sees clearly in a long distance.  If the patients uses bifocal glasses, the condition must be asses on the basis of the use of the distance glasses.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Newspaper text can be read, but the patient's eyes tire rapidly and/or he must hold the paper further away.|2, 2: The patient cannon read an ordinary newspaper text, but still manages to read texts printed in larger types.|3, 3: The patient can read large type, such a as headlines, only with aid, such as a magnifying glass.

1, 1: Salivation clearly increased, but not bothersome.|2, 2: Disturbing increase of salivation; need for spitting or frequent swallowing of saliva; only exceptional dribbling, perhaps concomitant speech disturbances.|3, 3: Frequent or constant dribbling, perhaps concomitant speech disturbances

Field Label: Dryness of mouth because of diminished salivation.  May result in increased consumption of liquids, buy must be distinguished from thirst.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slight dryness of mouth not disturbing to the patient.|2, 2: Moderate and slightly disturbing dryness of mouth.|3, 3: Dryness of mouth which clearly disturbs the patient's daily life.

Field Label: To be recorded on the basis of the last seven days.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slight nausea.|2, 2: Disturbing nausea, but without vomiting.|3, 3: Nausea and vomiting.

Field Label: Increased frequency and/or thinner consistency of feces.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Clearly present, but does not disturb work, or other performance.|2, 2: Disturbing, with need for several daily, inconvenient stools.|3, 3: Marked, imperative need for defecation, threatening or actual incontinence, results in frequent interruptions of work.

Field Label: Reduced frequency of defecation and/or thicker consistence of feces. (rate on pts response & if on laxative add 1 point)
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slight constipation, but bearable. (if take fiber = 1)|2, 2: More marked constipation which hampers the patient. (slight constipation on laxative =2)|3, 3: Very pronounced constipation.

Field Label: Feeling of difficulty in starting and of resistance to micturition, weaker stream and/or increased time of nicturition.  Should be assessed on the basis of the last 7 days.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Clearly present, but bearable.|2, 2: Poor stream, considerable increased time of micturition, feeling of incomplete emptying of bladder.|3, 3: Retention of urine with high volume residual urine and/or threatened or actual or acute retention.

Field Label: Increased urine production resulting in inreaced frequency of miturition and discharge of an abundant quantity of urine at each micturiton; secondarily increased consumption of fluid.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Clearly present, but not hampering. Nocturia:  At most once per night (in young people.|2, 2: Moderately hampering because of    frequent thirst, nocturia two or three times a night, or micturition more frequent than every two hours.|3, 3: Very hampering, almost constant thirst, nocturia at least four times a night, or micturition at least every hour.

Field Label: Palpitations, feeling of rapid, strong and/or irregular heartbeats.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Clearly present, but not hampering, only short occasional attacks or more constant, but not marked palpitations.|2, 2: Hampering frequent or constant palpitations that worries the patient or disturbs his night's sleep; however, without concomitant symptoms.|3, 3: Suspicion of real tachycardia, for instance because of concomitant feeling of weakness and need to lie down, dypsnea, tendency to fainting, or precordial pain.

Field Label: Localized to the whole body, not only palms and soles of the foot.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Clearly present, but mild, for example a profuse outburst of sweat only after considerable effort.|2, 2: Hampering, requires frequent change of clothes, profuse sweating after moderate activity, for instance walking upstairs.|3, 3: Profuse outbursts of sweat after slight activity or when resting, the patient is constantly wet, must change clothes several times a day and must also change night clothes or bedclothes.

1, 1: Localized to less than 5 percent of the skin surface, for instance to the palms.|2, 2: Scattered all over the skin, but covers less than 1/3 of the skin surface.|3, 3: Universal, i.e. covers more than 1/3 of the skin surface.

1, 1: Slight pruritus.|2, 2: Pronounced pruritus, so that the patient is being hampered.  There may be scratch marks.|3, 3: Severe pruritus that markedly hampers the patient.  There are distinct skin changes because of scratching.
1, 1: Slight, but not hampering.|2, 2: More pronounced and hampering to the patient.|3, 3: So pronounced that drug withdraw is clearly necessary.

Field Label: Increased skin pigmentation of brown or other color, often localized to parts of the skin exposed to light.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slightly increased pigmentation.|2, 2: Such marked pigmentation, generally or localized, that it worries the patient but is not conspicuous to others.|3, 3: So pronounced that the pigmentation can easily be observed by other people.

Field Label: The rating is to be made on the basis of the preceding month. May or may not be associated with increased appetite.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Weight gain amounting to 1-2 kg during the preceding month.|2, 2: Weight gain amounting to 3-4 kg during the preceding month.|3, 3: Weight gain amounting to more than 4 kg during the preceding month.

Field Label: The rating is to be made on the basis of the preceding month. May or may not be associated with reduced appetite.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Weight loss amounting to 1-2 kg during the preceding month.|2, 2: Weight loss amounting to 3-4 kg during the preceding month.|3, 3: Weight loss amounting to more than 4 kg during the preceding month.

Field Label: Hypermenorrhoea, polymenorrhoea, or metrorrhagia during the last 3 months.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Hypermenorrhoea, i.e. the menstrual flow is more intense than usla, the intervals being normal.|2, 2: Polymenorrhoea, i.e. the menstrual flow occurs more frequently and is more intense than normal.|3, 3: Metrorrhagia, i.e. irregular intervals and intensity, the blood loss being more frequent and intense compared with the usual pattern.

Field Label: Hypomenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, or amenorrhea during the last 3 months.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Hypomenorrhea, i.e. uterine bleeding of less than the normal amount, but occurring at normal intervals.|2, 2: Oligomenorrhea, i.e. prolonged intervals compared with the usual condition; the intensity may also be lower than usual.|3, 3: Amenorrhea, i.e. menstruation has been absent for more than 3 months.

Field Label: Increased secretion of milk outside periods of breast feeding.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Galactorrhea present, but to a very slight degree.|2, 2: Galactorrhea is present to a moderate degree and is felt to be somewhat disturbing.|3, 3: Galactorrhea is very pronounced and clearly disturbing.

Field Label: Excessive development of the mammary glands.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Gynecomastia present to a very slight degree compared with the usual state.|2, 2: Gynecomastia clearly present; however, only hampering when patient is undressed.|3, 3: Gynecomastia present to such a severe degree that it affects the patient cosmetically as it can be observed even if he is dressed.

1, 1: Slight increase, which is, however, still felt as natural by the partner.|2, 2: Clear increase that has given rise to comments and discussions with the partner.|3, 3: When the usual desire has increased to such a severe extent that the patient's life with his partner is considerably disturbed.

1, 1: The desire for sexual activity is slightly diminished, but without hampering the patient.|2, 2: A distinct reduction of the patient's desire for and interest in sexual activity so that it becomes a problem for the patient.|3, 3: Desire and interest have diminished to such an extent that sexual intercourse occurs extremely seldom or has stopped.

Field Label: Difficulty in attaining or maintaining an erection.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slightly diminished ability to attain or maintain an erection.|2, 2: A distinct change in the patient's ability to attain or maintain an erection.|3, 3: The patient only rarely (or never) can attain or maintain an erection.

Field Label: Dysfunction of the patient's ability to control ejaculation.  Includes a) premature or b) delayed ejaculation.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: It is somewhat more difficult than usual for the patient to control ejaculation, but it does not trouble him.|2, 2: A distinct change in the patient's ability to control ejaculation, so that is becomes a problem for him.|3, 3: The patient's ability to control ejaculation is influenced to such an extent that it has become a dominating problem in his sexual intercourse and thus to a great extent influences his experience of orgasm.

Field Label: Difficulty in obtaining and experiencing satisfactory orgasm.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: It is more difficult for the patient than usual to obtain orgasm and/or the experience of orgasm is slightly influenced.|2, 2: The patient states that there is a clear change in the ability to obtain orgasm and or in the experience of orgasm.  This change has reached such a degree that it troubles the patient.|3, 3: When the patient rarely or never can obtain orgasm and/or the experience of orgasm is markedly reduced.

Field Label: Dryness of vagina with sexual stimulation.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Slight dryness of vagina with sexual stimulation.|2, 2: Moderately disturbing dryness of vagina with sexual stimulation.|3, 3: Severely disturbing, marked dryness of vagina making coitus difficult (or necessitating the use of lubricants)

Field Label: Please list the side effect in 1 or 2 words.

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Mild: Discomfort noticed, but no disruption of normal daily activity|2, 2: Moderate: Discomfort sufficient to reduce or affect normal daily activity|3, 3: Severe: Incapacitating, with inability to work or to perform normal daily activity

Field Label: Decreased Appetite Without Weight Loss Severity.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Mild: Discomfort noticed, but no disruption of normal daily activity|2, 2: Moderate: Discomfort sufficient to reduce or affect normal daily activity|3, 3: Severe: Incapacitating, with inability to work or to perform normal daily activity

Field Label: Feeling of dizziness, weakness, everything going black, buzzing in the ears, or increased tendency to faint. May be associated with changing from supine or sitting position to upright position.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Clearly present, but requires no special countermeasures|2, 2: Hampering, but can be neutralized (for example, by slow and/or stagewise change to upright position).|3, 3: Threatening fainting or real episodes of fainting despite careful change of position, with a tendency to this type of dizziness as long as the patient is in an upright position.

Field Label: Note that falls are also assessed on the Decision Support Form and all falls should be captured there. Only falls resulting in reduced mobility, severe and persistent pain, or injury should be documented as Adverse Events. A fall resulting in injury and/or hospitalization should only be documented as one Adverse Event.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Mild: Discomfort noticed, but no disruption of normal daily activity.|2, 2: Moderate: Discomfort sufficient to reduce or affect normal daily activity.|3, 3: Severe: Incapacitating, with inability to work or to perform normal daily activity.
3, 3: Severe

Field Label: Increased Appetite Without Weight Gain Severity.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1: Mild: Noticeable, but no disruption of normal daily activity.|2, 2: Moderate: Discomfort sufficient to reduce or affect normal daily activity.|3, 3: Severe: Incapacitating, with inability to work or to perform normal daily activity.

Field Label: If Participant was not eligible for randomization: Select reason:

Field Label: 1. Did you have recent periods of two weeks or more when you felt depressed or uninterested in most things?
2. Do you think you got back to your usual self at any time since then, or have some symptoms still been bothering you the whole time?

Approximate Start of Episode

Now that we have talked about these problems, think back with me to when these symptoms started. When were you last feeling OK (your usual self)?

Say verbatim: "Now I would like to ask you some questions to check your memory and concentration. Some of them may be easy and some of them may be hard." <u>Ask all questions as they are written</u>. If preferred, you may record participants responses.

SAY: What year is it now?

(Acceptable Response: The exact year must be given. An incomplete but correct numerical response is acceptable (e.g., 01 for 2001).)

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0, Correct|1, Incorrect

Field Label:
SAY: What month is it now? 

(Acceptable response: The exact month must be given. A correct numerical answer is acceptable (e.g., 8 for August).)

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0, Correct|1, Incorrect

Field Label: SAY: I will give you a name and address to remember for a few minutes. Listen to me say the entire name and address and then repeat it after me. (It is important for the clinician to carefully read the phrase and give emphasis to each item of the phrase. There should be a one second delay between individual items. The trial phrase should be re-administered until the subject is able to repeat the entire phrase without assistance or until a maximum of three attempts. If the subject is unable to learn the phrase after three attempts, a "C" should be recorded. This indicates the subject could not learn the phrase in three tries. Whether or not the trial phrase is learned, the clinician should instruct "Good, now remember that name and address for a few minutes.")
Check off the words repeated correctly.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, John|2, Brown|3, 42|4, Market (Street)|5, Chicago

Field Label: Did the participant get Trial 1 completely correct?
Check off the words repeated correctly.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, John|2, Brown|3, 42|4, Market (Street)|5, Chicago

Field Label: Did the participant get Trial 2 completely correct?
Check off the words repeated correctly.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, John|2, Brown|3, 42|4, Market (Street)|5, Chicago

Field Label: SAY: Good, now remember that name and address for a few minutes.

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, 1|2, 2|3, 3|4, C (can't learn in 3 trials)

Field Label: SAY: Without looking at your watch or clock, tell me about what time it is. (This is scored as correct if the time given is within plus or minus one hour. If the subject's response is vague (e.g., "almost 1 o'clock), they should be prompted to give a more specific response.)

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0, Correct|1, Incorrect

Field Label:
SAY: Count aloud backwards from 20 to 1.

<em>(Mark incorrectly sequenced numerals, record incorrect responses; if the subject skips a number after 20, an error should be recorded. If the subject starts counting forward during the task or forgets the task, the instructions should be repeated and one error should be recorded. The maximum number of errors is two.)

SAY: Say the months of the year in reverse order. (To get the subject started, the examiner may state "Start with the last month of the year in a calendar year." If the subject cannot recall the last month of the year, the examiner may prompt this test with "The last month of the year is December." and one error should be recorded. If the subject skips a month, an error should be recorded. If the subject starts saying the months forward upon initiation of the task, the instructions should be repeated and no error recorded. If the subject starts saying the months forward during the task or forgets the task, the instructions should be repeated and one error recorded.)
(Mark INCORRECTLY sequenced months; record incorrect responses)

SAY: Repeat the name and address I asked you to remember. (The subject should state each item verbatim. The address number must be exact (i.e. "4200" would be considered an error for "42"). For the name of the street (i.e. Market Street), the thoroughfare term is not required to be given (i.e. Leaving off "drive" or street) or to be correct (i.e. substituting "boulevard" or "lane" for the item to be scored correct.)
Check off the words repeated correctly.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, John|2, Brown|3, 42|4, Market (Street)|5, Chicago

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Lithium|2, Quetiapine (Seroquel)|3, Aripiprazole (Abilify)|4, Olanzapine|5, Brexpiprazole (Rexulti)

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: INTERVIEWER: The questions in bold for each item should be asked exactly as written. Often these questions will elicit enough information about the severity and frequency of a symptom for you to rate the item with confidence. Follow-up questions are provided, however, for use when further exploration or additional clarification of symptoms is necessary. The specified questions should be asked until you have enough information to rate the item confidently. In some cases, you may also have to add your own follow-up questions to obtain necessary information. Note that questions in parentheses are optional, i.e., if information is unknown. NOTES: Time period. The ratings should be based on the patient's condition in the past week. Change from baseline. In general, a symptom is rated as present only when it reflects a change from before the depression began. The interviewer should try to identify a 2-month period of non-depressed functioning and use this as a reference point. In some cases, such as when the patient has Dysthymia, the referent should be to the last time they felt OK (i.e., not depressed or high) for at least a few weeks. *Remember: If symptom is endorsed by patient, to always consider duration, frequency, and impairment in functioning!
Please scan the MADRS and upload here.

OVERVIEW:  I'd like to ask you some questions about the past week.  How have you been feeling since last (DAY OF WEEK)?  IF OUTPATIENT: Have you been working?  (What kind of work do you do?)  IF NOT:  Why not?

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels:
0, 0 - No sadness. Appears happy during the interview.|1, 1 - Appears slightly down only momentarily during the interview|2, 2 - Looks dispirited but does brighten up without difficulty.
Appears down during the interview, but brightens up from time to time (e.g., laughing at a joke or amusing story; smiles when shaking hands w/ interviewer, etc.)|3, 3 - Appears sad during interview and only responds vaguely and with difficulty to positive interactions within the interview.|4, 4 - Appears sad and unhappy most of the time.
Appears sad and unhappy throughout interview. This is reflected both verbally and non-verbally.|5, 5 - Appears more severely down than a 4. (e.g., weeps throughout interview, etc.)|6, 6 - Looks miserable all the time. Extremely despondent.
As reflected in speech, facial expression, and posture

0, 0 - Occasional sadness in keeping with the circumstances.|1, 1 - Occasional reports of out-of-the-blue sadness.|2, 2 - Sad or low but brightens up without difficulty.|3, 3 - More frequent sadness than #2. Mood somewhat brightens to normal level, but only with difficulty, when pleasant events occur|4, 4 - Pervasive feelings of sadness or gloominess. The mood is still influenced by external circumstances. Mood never fully reaches "normal" brightening level, and is very brief in duration|5, 5 -Near continuous sadness. External circumstances no longer influence mood.|6, 6 - Continuous or unvarying sadness, misery, or despondency.

0, 0 - Placid. Only fleeting inner tension. Endorses a sense of inner calm, w/ only brief moments of tension or edginess.|1, 1 - Reports doubtful or trivial symptoms of inner turmoil, edginess, or tension, which are rare and cause little to no distress.|2, 2 - Occasional feelings of edginess and ill-defined discomfort. Endorses several occasions of tension/edginess that cause some discomfort. Distress is manageable, and does not impair functioning.|3, 3 - Reports frequent incidents of tension/edginess which cause moderate distress, and some impairment in functioning.|4, 4 - Continuous feelings of inner tension or intermittent panic which the patient can master with some difficulty. A nearly constant sense of anxiety and inner tension. Able to deal with symptoms, but they cause significant impairment in functioning.|5, 5 - Reports an inability to deal with these symptoms|6, 6 - Unrelenting dread or anguish. Overwhelming panic.
Severely impaired to a greater degree than a Symptoms are constant, overwhelming and severely debilitating.

0, 0 - Sleep as usual|1, 1 - Reports minimal sleep disruption (e.g., one night w/ mildly disturbed sleep).|2, 2 - Slight difficulty dropping off to sleep or slightly reduced, light, or fitful sleep.|3, 3 - Reports moderate sleep difficulties on several evenings during the week (e.g., 1-1/2 hour delay in falling asleep on several occasions; and/or waking 1-1 1/2 hours earlier than usual on several mornings).|4, 4 - Sleep reduced or broken by at least two hours.|5, 5 - Reports nightly sleep difficulties resulting in a reduction or disturbance of sleep by greater than 2 hours.|6, 6 - Less than two or three hours sleep.

0, 0 - Normal or increased appetite.|1, 1 - Reports a doubtful or trivial decrease in appetite.|2, 2 - Slightly reduced appetite. Reports mild decrease in appetite; the patient eats without encouragement by others, food intake is about normal.|3, 3 -Reports a moderate decrease in appetite, with a clearly reduced food intake.|4, 4 - No appetite. Food is tasteless. Endorses a severe loss of appetite; food intake is markedly decreased.|5, 5 - Patient is barely consuming any food.|6, 6 - Needs persuasion to eat at all. Loss of appetite is obvious and complete. Patient would stop eating entirely if not encouraged by others.

0, 0 - No difficulties in concentration.|1, 1 - Extremely mild, possibly doubtful difficulties in concentrating.|2, 2 - Occasional difficulties in collecting one's thoughts. Difficulties are infrequent and do not interfere with functioning.|3, 3 - Reports frequent difficulties collecting one's thoughts that do not significantly interfere with functioning.|4, 4 - Difficulties in concentrating and sustaining thought which reduces ability to read or hold a conversation. Reports a decreased ability to function due to concentration difficulties.|5, 5 - Reports pervasive difficulties and significantly impaired functioning.|6, 6 - Unable to read or converse without great difficulty. The patient is barely able to read or communicate, making the interview extremely difficult or impossible to complete

0, 0 - Hardly any difficulty in getting started. No sluggishness.|1, 1 - Reports a slight difficulty in starting one or two activities in the past week. This difficulty does not extend to multiple areas and does not interfere with the ability to function.|2, 2 - Difficulties in starting activities. Clearly endorses difficulty, however, once activities are started the patient is able to carry them out.|3, 3 - Patient has pervasive difficulties starting activities in many different areas.|4, 4 - Difficulties in simple routine activities which are carried out with effort. Difficulties starting even simple routines (e.g., basic chores, grooming, etc.). Once these routines are started, patient has difficulty completing them.|5, 5 - Pervasive difficulties in multiple areas of functioning. Functioning is severely affected.|6, 6 - Complete lassitude. Unable to do anything without help. Unable to initiate or complete any tasks without assistance.

0, 0 - Normal interest in the surroundings and in other people.|1, 1 - Reports slightly reduced pleasure or interest in people or certain activities. Most people and activities are still as interesting and enjoyable.|2, 2 - Reduced ability to enjoy usual interests. Reports getting clearly less pleasure or enjoyment from some activities.|3, 3 - A marked loss of pleasure in many activities.|4, 4- Loss of interest in the surroundings. Loss of feelings for friends and acquaintances. Patient has clearly lost interest in most activities, and/or reports a loss of emotion or feelings towards some people.|5, 5 - Patient has lost feelings and interest for most people and activities.|6, 6 - The experience of being emotionally paralyzed, inability to feel anger, grief, or pleasure, and a complete or even painful failure to feel for close relatives and friends.

0, 0 - No pessimistic thoughts. Reports no pessimism OR self-criticism|1, 1 - Reports feeling slightly self-critical or mildly pessimistic about the future.|2, 2 - Fluctuating ideas of failure, self-reproach, or self-depreciation. Pt is clearly self-critical on occasion. Such feelings are not persistent.|3, 3 - Feels self-critical on more days than not, and/or is clearly discouraged about the future.|4, 4 - Persistent self-accusations, or definite but still rational ideas of guilt or sin. Increasingly pessimistic about the future. Endorses constant feelings of self-criticism or guilt, and/or is increasingly pessimistic and severely discouraged about the future.|5, 5 - Patient's negative thoughts about the self or future border on "delusional," but do not quite reach that level of severity.|6, 6 - Delusions of ruin, remorse, or unredeemable sin. Self-accusations which are absurd and unshakable.

Field Label: 10. This past week, have you felt like life isn't worth living?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0, 0 - Enjoys life or takes it as it comes. Denies suicidal ideation or a feeling that life is not worth living.|1, 1 - Endorses a vague, transient sense that life is not worth living, without any specific wishes to die or thoughts of self-harm.|2, 2 - Weary of life. Only fleeting suicidal thoughts. Reports a sense that life is not worth living, and has had some passing thoughts of suicide. There is no specific plan or intent for self-harm.|3, 3 - Endorses frequent thoughts of self-harm and a strong sense that life is not worth living, without any specific plan or intent to die. Suicide is not considered an option.|4, 4 - Probably better off dead. Suicidal thoughts are common, and suicide is considered as a possible solution, but without specific plans or intention. Actively considering suicide as an option, without any specific plans or intentions.|5, 5 - Patient has a specific plan for suicide and a strong wish to die, without having made a firm decision to carry it out.|6, 6 - Explicit plans for suicide when there is an opportunity. Active preparations for suicide. Patient would kill himself/herself if they had the chance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Lithium|2, Quetiapine (Seroquel)|3, Aripiprazole (Abilify)|4, Olanzapine|5, Brexpiprazole (Rexulti)

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Lithium|2, Quetiapine (Seroquel)|3, Aripiprazole (Abilify)|4, Olanzapine|5, Brexpiprazole (Rexulti)

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Lithium|2, Quetiapine (Seroquel)|3, Aripiprazole (Abilify)|4, Olanzapine|5, Brexpiprazole (Rexulti)

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.
