Field Label: Augmentation Therapy Some patients will have taken medications that qualify as a combination/ augmentation trial. 1) In general, an antidepressant monotherapy trial will precede the addition of an augmentation agent. The antidepressant monotherapy trial should be rated alone. 2) Only specified antipsychotics (i.e., aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine, brexiprazole) and lithium are considered augmenting agents. 3) DO NOT rate the antipsychotic or lithium trials alone (unless they were taken alone --i.e., without an antidepressant). Instead, input both the antidepressant and the augmentation agent as a standalone trial with the duration that the two medications were taken together at their maximum doses. 4) In the scenario where an antidepressant and an eligible augmentation agent were started at the same time, rate the augmentation trial only and do not rate the antidepressant alone. 5) If two antidepressants are taken in combination this does not constitute an augmentation trial and each antidepressant should be rated alone (i.e., a patient taking venlafaxine and mirtazapine together is considered to have received two separate antidepressant trials). 6) If ECT and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 7) If rTMS and medications are given simultaneously, this does not constitute a combination/augmentation trial. Each should be rated separately. 8) If medication and psychotherapy occurred together rate each alone. This does not constitute an augmentation trial. 9) Combination of antidepressant with lamotrigine does not constitute an augmentation trial. 10) Combination of antidepressant with lurasidone does not constitute an augmentation trial.

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Lithium|2, Quetiapine (Seroquel)|3, Aripiprazole (Abilify)|4, Olanzapine|5, Brexpiprazole (Rexulti)

Field Label: Would like to view information on how to determine "Confidence Rating"?

Low Confidence Rating: Information is marginal. Some contradictions in information or doubt exists regarding dose, duration, or compliance. Moderate Confidence Rating: Adequate information is available but based largely on one source that appears reliable. Areas of doubt not critical in rating. Strong Confidence Rating: Adequate information available from more than one reliable source without significant discrepancy regarding dose, duration, or compliance.

Field Note: Data mgmt resolution documentation

Field Label: Hello, my name is [insert name] from Washington University in St. Louis-School of Medicine. I'm calling about the OPTIMUM Neuro study that you are already participating in. We are conducting follow-up phone calls with our participants, checking-in on how you are doing, and seeing if you might be interested in answering some questions related to how the COVID-19 outbreak might be affecting you. Would you be interested in learning more about this part of the study? Please feel free to ask questions at any time.
Is the participant interested in learning more about the study?
<font size=3, color="blue"><center>Thank you for your time and consideration.</center></font>

• These surveys will take approximately 45 minutes to complete over the phone. Questions are regarding your exposure to the COVID-19 outbreak, as well as typical ways it might affect you, including changes in your thoughts, feelings, sleep, and activity levels.
  • The goal of these surveys/assessments is to better understand the impact of COVID-19.
  • You may skip any question you prefer not to answer and you can end the interview at any time.
  • There is no cost to you or your insurer to participate in this telephone interview.
  • You will be paid $35 for participating in these questions.
  • The National Institutes of Health (NIH) is funding this research study.

    • A risk of participating in these additional questions is that confidential information about you may be accidentally disclosed. The questions could cause fatigue or emotional discomfort. You will not benefit from participating in these additional questions.

    We will ask that you are in a private space where you feel comfortable talking. You may choose not to answer any question with which you feel uncomfortable. You can also request to take breaks and continue at another time.

    We will keep the information you provide confidential. Data from this research will be kept in a locked file cabinet and secured password database. Your identity on these records will be indicated by a code number rather than by your name, and the information linking the case number with your identity will be kept separate from the research records. Any report or article that we write will not include information that can directly identify you. However, federal regulatory agencies and Washington University, including the Washington University Institutional Review Board (a committee that reviews and approves research studies) and the Human Research Protection Office may inspect and copy records pertaining to this research activity.

    Your participation in these additional surveys is completely voluntary. You may choose not to take part at all. If you decide to participate in these questions, you may stop participating at any time. Any data that was collected as part of these surveys will remain as part of the study records and cannot be removed. If you decide not to take part in the surveys, or if you stop participating at any time, you won't be penalized or lose any benefits for which you otherwise qualify.

    As part of the surveys, you will be asked questions that will generate Protected Health Information, or PHI. PHI is health information that identifies you and is protected by law under HIPAA (the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act). To take part in these questions you must give the research team permission to use and disclose your PHI for this study as explained during the consent process for the additional questions. The research team will follow state and federal laws and it is possible that other people may become aware of your participation in these assessments and may inspect records pertaining to the research. This could include university representatives, to complete university responsibilities and government representatives, (including the Office for Human Research Protections and the Food and Drug Administration) to complete federal or state responsibilities, the National Institutes of Health (NIH), and the investigators at the additional sites of the Optimum Neuro Study.

    Once your health information is shared with someone outside of the research team, it may no longer be protected by HIPAA.

    The research team will only use and share your information as talked about during this consent process. When possible, the research team will make sure information cannot be linked to you (de-identified). Once information is de-identified, it may be used and shared for other purposes not discussed during this consent process. If you have questions or concerns about your privacy and the use of your PHI, please contact the University's Privacy Officer at 866-747-4975.

    Although you will not be allowed to see the study information, you may be given access to your health care records by contacting your health care provider.

    If you do not agree to allow us to use your PHI it will not affect your treatment or the care given by your health provider, insurance payments or enrollment in any health plans, or any benefits to which you are entitled. However, it will not be possible for you to take part in the study. If you agree, you authorize the use of your PHI for this research, and your authorization will not expire. You may later change your mind and not let the research team use or share your information.

    In order to revoke your authorization, you will need to complete a withdrawal letter. Please contact the Human Research Protection Office for more information on how to revoke your authorization or contact the research team to request the withdrawal letter. If you revoke your authorization, the research team may only use and share information already collected for the study. Your information may still be used and shared as necessary to maintain the integrity of the research, for example, to account for a participant's withdrawal from the research study or for safety reasons. You will not be allowed to continue to participate in the study.

    We encourage you to ask questions. If you have any questions about the research study itself, please contact: Marissa Rhea at 314-362-3797. If you have questions, concerns, or complaints about your rights as a research participant, please contact the Human Research Protection Office at 1-(800)-438-0445 or email hrpo@wustl.edu. General information about being a research participant can be found on the Human Research Protection Office web site, http://hrpo.wustl.edu. To offer input about your experiences as a research participant or to speak to someone other than the research staff, call the Human Research Protection Office at the number above.
Do you agree to participate in these additional questions?
<font size=3, color="blue"><center>Thank you for your time and consideration.</center></font>
